newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee steady vs dlr in fwd, quiet in spot.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee steady vs dlr in fwd, quiet in spot.

text.p: The Indian rupee was steady against the dollar in both the forward and spot markets in late morning trade Friday, dealers said.
They said the rupee opened marginally down against the forward dollar but was steady at the lower level.
November-delivery dollars were quoted at a premium of 87/90 paise against the previous clsoe of 86/89, dealers said.
"Forward premiums were marginally up in anticipation of higher call money rates," said a dealer at a foreign bank.
He said the announcement of a 30 billion rupee three-year federal government bond auction for May 28 had led to fears liquidity will tighten and pushed premiums up slightly.

"But call money looks fairly stable and forward premiums have stabilised at levels marginally higher from the last close," the dealer said. "The market is quite steady with demand and supply evenly matched."
Dealers said the rupee was steady in the spot market with most of the trade between 35.7750 and 35.7775 per dollar.
The rupee opened Thursday at 35.77/78, up from Wednesday's close of 35.790/795.
The forex market was largely inactive on Thursday as banks in the commercial capital of Bombay and some other centres were closed for a local holiday.
"So far the Reserve Bank of India has not come to the market," said a dealer. "In their absence the rupee will drift up gently on strong dollar supply and light demand."
In latest deals, the dollar was quoted 35.775/785 rupees.
